Bloomfield points out that the gold inflows wereprimarily caused by huge net imports of foreign capital to the U.S; the U.S.ran persistent and large capital account surpluses in the mid— and late—19305.17 He then states: "Probably the most important single cause of themassive movement of funds to the United States in 1934—39 as a whole was therapid deterioration in the international political situation. The growingthreat of a European war created fears of seizure or destruction of wealth bythe enemy, imposition of exchange restrictions, oppressive war taxation .
